report_title: Credit Card Issuing in the US
executive_summary: The Credit Card Issuing industry in the US provides transaction and credit services to consumers and businesses by issuing credit cards with available credit lines that must be repaid in full to the issuer, often in installments. Commercial banks are excluded from this industry since credit card issuance is not a primary business activity. Industry operators generate revenue from cardholders primarily through fees and interest earned on revolving credit. Companies compete by offering customers lower interest rates, flexible and secure payment options and rewards programs based on spending levels.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: The COVID-19 Pandemic and Subsequent Inflationary Pressures Have Killed Consumer Appetites to Spend
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Credit card issuers are reliant on credit card transaction volumes to generate income. That being said, the consumer sentiment index has fluctuated violently following the COVID-19 outbreak. Inflationary pressures that followed the pandemic have compounded consumer sentiment declines with many people opting to pay down debts and avoid taking on more due to wider economic uncertainty.

Over the years to 2028, competing economic trends and technology adoption will determine industry growth. Performance will continue to improve as concerns surrounding the coronavirus subside and consumer spending returns to pre-pandemic levels. However, while national unemployment is expected to decline and support demand for credit cards, Federal Reserve Board actions to stem mounting inflation may threaten revenue generation.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Rising costs of utilities and food are forcing consumers to utilize credit cards more to purchase necessities.
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Credit card issuers make profit based on the difference between interest charged on balances and the interest paid on deposits used to fund credit cards. The Federal Reserve's aggressive interest rate hikes has harmed industry profit margins, as wholesale funding costs and interest expenses have risen in response. Credit card issuers have either had to raise average lending rates or accept lower margins.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Alternative Payment Methods Have Drawn Customers Away From Credit Cards
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Many customers have opted for alternative payment forms like buy now pay later (BNPL) services or debit cards. Australia's younger demographics in particular have shown preference for differing payment methods. Least-cost routing initiatives, which have been supported by the RBA have reduced fees charged on debit card transactions making them an even cheaper alternative to credit cards.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Credit Card Issuers Have Adopted the Tools of the Competition to Stay Relevant
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Alternative payment methods like BNPL services, and digital payment platforms such as ShopPay, Afterpay and Affirm have posed a significant threat to the industry.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Interest Rate Hikes Will Continue to Pressure Credit Card Profit Margins
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Higher interest rates are on track to continue constraining credit card profit margins because of rising wholesale funding costs through heightened interest expenses. Credit card issuers will continue raising average lending rates to preserve profit margin. Some credit card issuers may buck the trend of rising lending rates, and maintain or lower their rates. In this fashion credit card issuers can differentiate themselves from the competition through pricing strategies.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Easing Economic Pressures Will Encourage Greater Use of Credit Cards
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Heightened interest rates are projected to rein in inflation over the next one to two years as the overheated economy cools down. Credit card issuers are poised to benefit from rebounds in consumer spending as a lot of households use credit as a means to purchase larger items.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Shifting Attitudes Toward Credit Use Are Set to Frustrate Card Issuers
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Younger demographics aversions to credit card use are set to continue with many consumers opting for cheaper alternatives like BNPL services, debit card use and other fintech products.

industry_definition: The Credit Card Issuing industry issues credit cards, providing the funds required to buy goods and services in return for payment on a full balance or installment basis. Credit cards issued in the United States are not issued directly by Visa Inc. (Visa), MasterCard Incorporated (MasterCard) or any other payment-solution organization. Rather, Visa, MasterCard and other similar corporations provide the actual payment systems used when payments are made by credit card.

positive_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level high - steady

key_trends: Interest rate hikes are constricting credit card issuer profit because of rising wholesale funding costs. Inflated expense costs have squeezed the spread between average lending rates and funding costs.

Consumer preference is shifting to cheaper alternatives, like buy now pay later services and debit cards. To stay relevant, credit card issuers are starting to add services such as online and mobile payments.
Regulations for credit card issuers are reducing revenue-generating segments, including interchange fees. Credit card issuers are bringing on more employees to stay in compliance.

Rising inflation is causing the consumer price index to increase. Recessionary fears and rising costs are causing discretionary spending on credit cards to pull back, although more consumers are having to purchase utility and food through credit.
Younger customers are hesitant to take on debt and have been drawn to interest-free alternatives like BNPL services.
Reward cards offer a lot of benefits to maintain interest. To justify higher rates, credit card issuers organize a wide range of rewards like cashback arrangements and airport lounge access.
Branch level service works best in big cities where issuers have access to large pools of potential customers.
Credit card issuers are moving intake channels online. Customers can apply for new credit cards through online portals and mobile apps, which has reduced the need for face-to-face service.
Payment types that don't charge interest are popular alternatives in the payment market. Consumers are drawn by the price competitiveness of interest-free options.
The price of credit dictates competition between issuers, with companies undercutting each other and offering lower interest rate cards to attract customers.
Banks can cross-sell their credit cards with loan packages. People applying for car and home loans can also access cards with reduced rates.

market_segmentation.segment: Economic Uncertainty is Reducing Business Credit Card Usage
market_segmentation.segment_description: Businesses use credit cards to finance large purchases and typically have higher credit limits than that of consumers. Businesses represent a significant market for credit card issuers as they engage in high volumes of transactions with high values. Businesses have paid down credit card balances due to the economic uncertainty associated with the coronavirus pandemic and subsequent inflationary pressures.

market_segmentation.segment: Younger Consumers Gravitate to Alternative Financing
market_segmentation.segment_description: Card holders aged 22-35, also known as Gen Y (Millennials) hold an average of 3 credit cards and an average balance of $4,576. Card holders under the age of 21 require a parent to co-sign in order to obtain a credit card. This leads to this group to hold the smallest average number of cards and the smallest balances. Younger consumers are turning to alternatives for financing.

Card holders aged 71 and older hold an average of 4 credit cards with an average balance of $3,177. Older demographics, including retirees, display an affinity for rewards programs. Older customers enjoy the use of reward points for flyer miles, gifts and cashback arrangements.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Merchants are Fighting Back Against Credit Processing Fees
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Large businesses are circumventing interchange fees by issuing credit cards through their own finance arm, increasing their bargaining power to bring down interchange fees. Certain merchants are offering incentives for consumers to pay with cash or debit card in order to avoid incurring an interchange fee.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Federal Reserve's Aggressive Rate Hikes are Benefiting Revenue Gains from Interest
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Interest revenue is primarily generated through the debt associated on a credit card that accumulates over time. Rising expenses because of rampant inflation is causing credit card users to incur interest fees associated with late repayment. Rising interest rates are enabling credit card issuers to increase interest rates, gaining additional interest revenue.

demand_determinants.determinant_title: Consumers gravitate towards no annual fee cards
demand_determinants.determinant_description: Credit card issuers also derive revenue from various types of cardholder fees. Consumers are becoming increasingly wary of credit cards with yearly fees attached to them. More credit cards are being offered without any fees associated with them to draw in more consumers, reducing the amount of revenue credit card issuers derive from this segment.

business_locations.location_description: The Mid-Atlantic accounts for the second largest share of credit card issuing establishments. Major commercial banks reside in New York, lending to credit card issuers also having a strong presence. Equally important in the region is the state of Delaware, which gives tax and legal benefits to credit card issuers who reside there.

The southeast accounts for the largest share of credit card issuing establishments. Most of these establishments are located in Florida, benefiting from a large population. Florida is also facing a large influx of people moving to the state.
The west accounts for the fourth largest share of credit card issuing establishments.

regulations_points.regulation_description: Credit card banks are subject to capital requirements and guidelines that the Federal Reserve Board imposes on bank holding companies. The OCC, the Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC) and the Federal Reserve Board impose similar requirements on banks within respective jurisdictions. These capital requirements establish higher capital standards for banks and bank holding companies that assume greater risks.
The Truth in Lending Act is a federal law designed to protect consumers in credit transactions by requiring disclosure of the lending arrangement and all costs associated with borrowing.

The Schumer Box, named after Senator Charles Schumer, also aims to add transparency to advertising of credit card issuers. The credit card issuer must disclose the annual percentage rate, finance charges, minimum payment required, the method used for computing a customer's outstanding balance, the credit limit, grace period, annual fee and fees for credit insurance, if any. All credit cards use the same format, making comparison shopping easier for the consumer and enabling credit card issuers to compete on the basis of fees and terms.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Credit Card Accountability, Responsibility and Disclosure (CARD) Act of 2009
regulations_points.regulation_description: The Credit CARD Act bans rate increases on existing balances due to universal defaults and it severely restricts rate increases due to late payments. The Act provides greater fee transparency and accountability as issuers need to make contracts available on the internet in a usable format. Lastly, the Act places strict limits on marketing and issuing cards to young people. Consumers that are younger than 21 need to show proof of income to repay card loans or have an adult co-sign to establish accounts.

This law established the Consumer Financial Protection Act of 2010, forcing credit card issuers to develop and implement new technologies that adhere to regulations enforcing consumer rights and increasing security surrounding financial information. Many companies have been forced to increase its work force to keep up with an ever-changing complex set of compliance issues.

regulations_points.regulation_title: The Credit Card Competition Act of 2022
regulations_points.regulation_description: The Credit Card Competition Act of 2022 (S.4674) and a house companion introduced by Representatives Welch and Gooden will impact competition in the credit card issuer marketplace by addressing the number of networks on which a credit transaction may be processed. The bill intends to bring competition and choice to the network participants thus reducing interchange fees and revenue to industry operators.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Top four players dominate credit card issuance
concentration_points.concentration_description: The top four largest players include American Express Company, Synchrony Financial, Capital One Financial Corporation and Discover Financial Services. The top four players account for 42.2% of revenue in 2023.

concentration_points.concentration_title: Large enterprises are not the norm
concentration_points.concentration_description: According to the latest data available from the US Census, 68.2% of employer operators only employ between one and five workers.

cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Credit card issuers are using technology and outsourcing to drive down wage costs. Salespeople and customer service personnel are employed across branch networks, offices and call centers. Day-to-day banking services provide a strong cross-selling opportunity for industry operators and client-facing staff are trained and tasked to sell credit card products with other services. Some issuers have streamlined distribution channels, increased technology use, employed more part-time staff and outsourced certain administrative functions.

Credit card issuers make their profit margins on the spread between the interest charged on client balances and the interest paid on deposits used to fund issued credit cards. The low interest rate environment that issuers enjoyed over the past decade allowed them to charge relatively high average lending rates and generate desirable profit margins. The raising of interest rates is causing increases in wholesale funding costs and interest paid on deposits, thereby closing the size of credit card spreads and constricting profit to 26.8% of industry revenue in 2023.
Credit card issuers expand marketing amidst rising competition. The most popular way to advertise its card is through the use of direct mail and email.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The industry needs labor for customer service operations as staff can match the right type of credit card to the customer. Staff are also usually trained to carry out the administrative and processing tasks associated with issuing credit cards.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_title: Low rate of new patent technologies
capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: The rate of new patent technologies entering the industry is low, which limits the potential for innovations. A low rate does not mean that innovations cannot occur, just that the likelihood of some innovation materializing as a threat is lower.
However, the concentration of technologies is high in this industry. This suggests that industry operators have exposure to potentially unforeseen areas of innovation.

The major markets for this industry are highly concentrated, which implies that the market has a focus on key customer segments. This presents an opportunity for strategic entrance into lower-end markets or unserved markets for innovations to take on a disruptive trajectory.

volatility_points.volatility_title: Interest rate hikes contributing to volatility
volatility_points.volatility_description: Recent guidance from the Federal Reserve indicates that interest rates are not lowering significantly any time soon. Lowered consumer spending has directly flowed through to the industry with less purchases being made on credit cards. Higher interest rates have caused of higher average rates charged on credit balances outstanding, due to rises in wholesale funding costs and interest paid on deposits. The rise in average rates has been offset by the detrimental effect higher rates have had on customers appetites for credit cards.

As credit card issuers make a lot of their money from interest paid on credit borrowed, lower amounts of consumer spending translate to lower revenue for the industry. The ratio of credit card debt to discretionary income has gradually trended downward over the past five years which has raised credit card revenue volatility. Customers have shown preference for paying down debts, particularly against the backdrop of the coronavirus pandemic and subsequent inflationary pressures.
Credit card issuers also make money from annual fees charged to card holder regardless of how much they have spent, which limits industry volatility.
The wide variety of alternative payment options has raised industry volatility. Traditionally credit cards were the simplest and easiest way for customers to make online purchases.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Merchants fighting back against credit processing fees
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Interchange fees, sometimes referred to as merchant fees, are the fees that credit processors charge merchants for accepting credit cards. Large businesses are circumventing interchange fees by issuing credit cards through their own finance arm, increasing their bargaining power to bring down interchange fees. For example, Walmart is offering a credit card through the Walmart Money Center. Certain merchants are offering incentives for consumers to pay with cash or debit card in order to avoid incurring an interchange fee.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Federal Reserve's rate hikes benefiting revenue gains
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Interest revenue is primarily generated through the debt associated on a credit card that accumulates over time. Rising expenses because of rampant inflation is causing credit card users to incur interest fees associated with late repayment. Rising interest rates are enabling credit card issuers to increase interest rates, gaining additional interest revenue. In response to rising fees, consumers are utilizing buy now pay later (BNPL) services to avoid interest fees.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Consumers gravitating towards no annual fee cards
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Credit card issuers also derive revenue from various types of cardholder fees. These fees include card cancellation fees, late payment fees, non-usage charges and credit insurance fees. Consumers are becoming increasingly wary of credit cards with yearly fees attached to them. More credit cards are being offered without any fees associated with them to draw in more consumers, reducing the amount of revenue credit card issuers derive from this segment. These cards are convenient for purchasers who like the convenience of having a credit card for an occasional large purchase or for online shopping.

FAQs.question: How do you emphasize the value of your company's services?
FAQs.answer: Credit card companies try to emphasize the value of their services through their rewards programs and interest rates on their credit cards. Additionally, having a variety of financing options available to customers proved to be valuable during the COVID-19 pandemic as more customers looked to extend payments due to decreasing employment levels.

FAQs.question: What media channels are you using to attract consumers and investors, if any?
FAQs.answer: Credit card issuers use traditional media channels such as TV, print and the internet to attract consumers and businesses. Specifically, having a robust online marketing strategy as proved to be key to the success of many credit card companies, as more business has been conducted online during the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020 and 2021.

FAQs.question: Are your operations spread across the country or are your establishments more concentrated in a certain geographic location?
FAQs.answer: Credit card issuers are starting to consolidate their operations and limit the geographic reach of their operations to safeguard client information. This has proved beneficial during the COVID-19 pandemic as it is easier to manage the social distancing requirements in one single location. Issuing credit cards to clients more broadly across the country has proved to be beneficial during the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020 and 2021, as different.

FAQs.question: How do you ensure that you stay up to date with software and technology trends?
FAQs.answer: Credit card issuers have needed to improve their technology to comply with a variety of regulations levied against them. Additionally, stay up-to-date on a variety of technologies for web design and payment processing allows operators to maintain a competitive advantage compared to its competitors.

FAQs.question: How have you taken advantage of rising internet and mobile internet penetration into the financial services industry?
FAQs.answer: Credit card issuers have benefited from a higher percentage of services being conducted online since they are primarily completed by using credit cards. This trend has continued considerably in 2020 and 2021 as e-commerce sales have rapidly rose during the COVID-19 pandemic.

FAQs.question: How do you expect the proposed changes to Dodd-Frank to affect your business?
FAQs.answer: Dodd-Frank's enactment affected credit card issuers in that it increased regulatory oversight through the formation of the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. Credit card issuers must continue to monitor new change and policy recommendations that the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau suggests, in order to assure they are following guidelines.

FAQs.question: How have increased capital requirements under Basel III affected operations?
FAQs.answer: Credit card issuers do not experience capital requirements under Basel III.

FAQs.question: Do you have enough capital reserved to be able to invest in new technology/software as soon as it becomes available?
FAQs.answer: Credit card issuers are generally well-capitalized and able to purchase new technology when needed. Having capital available proved beneficial for businesses in 2020, as it allowed them to invest in new technology needed to seamlessly operate during the COVID-19 pandemic, as well as to sustain expected loan losses from customers unable to pay their bills.

FAQs.question: How do your profit margins compare to those of your competitors'?
FAQs.answer: Credit card issuers' profit margins fluctuate based on interest rates on credit cards, in addition to their clients paying down outstanding debts. However, industry profit margins substantially declined in 2020 as a result of consumers being unable to pay their bills, which lead to expected loan losses for operators, during the COVID-19 pandemic. As concerns surrounding the pandemic wane in 2021 and economic activity returns to normal levels, profit margins with the industry are expected to improve in 2021.

FAQs.question: Is your technical expertise to a world standard? How do you achieve and maintain good product quality? How do you keep costs low when doing so?
FAQs.answer: Operators must be able to adopt the latest information technology (especially in delivery systems) that is cost-effective to provide customers with the best possible service. It is particularly important that operators have the ability to bill customers digitally without necessarily needing a paper receipt of bills, along with online bill paying and finance management platforms.

FAQs.question: How do you maintain customer satisfaction?
FAQs.answer: Understanding the needs of consumers and providing them with a product that meets their needs is crucial to the success of a credit card issuing company. Specific ways that credit card companies maintain customer satisfaction is via reward payments, top-tier payment processing platforms and technology, and high-quality customer service.

FAQs.question: What kind of transportation do you rely on to deliver your products?
FAQs.answer: It is important to establish a network of customers (credit card banks) to distribute the products (credit cards) to customers through a well-developed branch, online and mail network. Being able to rely on delivering products and services mainly online has been vital during the COVID-19 pandemic.

FAQs.question: How closely does your business follow trends in aggregate household debt?
FAQs.answer: Higher credit card usage leads to increased industry revenue, as both payments to principal and interest accrue, pushing revenue higher.

FAQs.question: How closely do you follow the prime rate?
FAQs.answer: The average interest rate charged by credit card issuers is typically linked to changes in the prime rate. As the prime rate rises, interest revenue generated by the industry increases as well.

FAQs.question: Do you monitor the business sentiment index? How will you promote temporary staffers over permanent ones as sentiment improves further?
FAQs.answer: Businesses feeling more confident in their long-term financial stability is usually an indicator that consumers are spending, to the benefit of industry operators.
